newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money ends unchanged, gilt yields down.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money ends unchanged, gilt yields down.

text.p: Indian call ended Friday in the 10.50-10.75 percent range, unchanged from the day's opening levels, dealers said.
In tight range-bound trade, most of the day's deals were struck between 10.65 and 10.75 percent, they said.

Dealers said call money remained tight despite rumours of an impending cut in cash reserve requirements. The monetary policy for October-April is expected to be announced by the Reserve Bank of India in the first week of October.
Money market dealers said they expected a cut in cash reserve requirements from the existing 12 percent.
Security prices rose on buying pressure, dealers said.
"Market participants seem to be building up positions in short-term securities," a primary dealer said.

The 13.50 percent 1997 government of India stock traded on Friday at a yield of 13.17 percent against 13.22 percent on Thursday while the 13.50 percent 1998 stock traded at 13.49 percent against 13.54 percent, dealers said.

Dealers said there was little activity in certificates of deposit (CDs). "Given that most banks are enjoying good liquidity and there is little demand for credit, it makes little sense to pick up CDs at 11 percent," a dealer said.
Commercial paper by top-rated companies were quoted around 13 percent in the primary market, dealers said.
Rates on intercorporate deposits remained steady in the 17-19 percent range for top-rated borrowers, dealers said.
